content:
Validator 5 is the only one to cross from negative to positive years, and the answer suggests that there is such a thing as "Year 0" and that it's a leap year.

1. There should be a test case also that crosses the negative to positive years.
2. In the common AD/CE calendar system, there was no year 0. 1 BC/BCE was followed by 1 AD/CE.

You state in the statement that Gregory was born on Feb 29. This means he is born in a leap year - in other words, in my code I can loop over a range starting from his birth year, check for leaps, and distract with one (because I should exclude the birth year).
Sadly, however, this does not work, because in your input the year of birth is not always a leap year. Eg 1974 and 1975 are not leap years.

Please change your statement or change the input of those cases, because at this moment it is incorrect.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to understand and a little bit complicated but good for a Clash of Code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great job. It can be quickly solved. Your solution is working and mine too. It can quickly solved.
There is already 1000 Clash about leap year

Hi! There seems to be a problem either in my head or in your testcases. If Iam born in the year 2000 and have an age of 0 years, there is one (and not zero, Validator 1) leap year. Also in 'Easy' there are four leap years, not three. See for example here https://miniwebtool.com/leap-years-list/?start_year=2000&end_year=2012

However, there are no problems in my head with the other testcases :)
Very good! Maybe you could add or edit a test, which go throw positive/ negative values (eg: age[50],  year[24])

Nice calculation problem!
Maybe you can add a validator with age=0?

Input section
* Line 1: Please add "An integer for".

* Line 2: Please add "An integer for".

Constraints section
* Please correct the variable names.

Cases
* I don't even know in which year when the concept of leap year became effective - should negative years (that is B.C.) be really tested?

* Please correct the constraints and/or the cases so that they are consistent. "Negative" years are outside the constraint.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.
Thanks I've made the changes. And leap years were created by Julius Caesar in 47 BC, so I changed the tests.
The goal is to give the number of birthdays celebrated during a leap year, so the year of birth does not count, but I will modify the statement to make it more understandable :)

Yeah, this is an issue, but it's hard to edit the clash on behalf of the author because it would probably mean just changing the whole title and concept, simplifying it to just "count the leap years in the [[n]] years from [[year]]+1".

I guess the author is inactive now though.

It's not that big a deal in the end because at least there's a test that shows you can't trust [[year]] being leap, just invalidates the statement.
